# {{lb|fr|informal|figuratively|of a [[fog]]}} [[very]] [[dense]], very [[thick]], thick as a [[pea soup]]
#: {{coi|fr|un brouillard '''à couper au couteau'''|a [[pea-souper]]}}
#* {{quote-book
|fr
|year=2010
|author=Michel Castaigna
|title=La Dictée miraculeuse
|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=ejv7umwhsFgC&pg=PA37&dq=%22brouillard+à+couper+au+couteau%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4y_znuffmAhUtzMQBHRsFBpk4FBDoAQg1MAE#v=onepage&q=%22brouillard%20à%20couper%20au%20couteau%22&f=false
|page=37
|passage=Deux heures du matin, se disait-il, moins dix degrés, un brouillard '''à couper au couteau''', un quartier sans intérêt, un mot de passe débile, quelques sous-officiers et sentinelles sans la moindre motivation et cinq cents troufions qui roupillent en attendant le jus tiède du matin [...]|t=Two o'clock in the morning, he thought, minus ten degrees, a '''pea-souper''' of a fog, nothing interesting in the area, a stupid password, a few NCOs and sentries who had not a shred of motivation, and five-hundred squaddies dozing off as they waited for their warm juice in the morning {{...}}}}
# {{lb|fr|informal|figuratively|of an [[accent]]}} very [[heavy]], very [[thick]], very [[strong]]; that you could cut with a knife
#* {{quote-book
|fr
|year=2005
|author=Julie Poirier
|title=Au hasard des pistes : Les deux Amériques à vélo
|isbn=2951991088
|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=-NOBiO1DJ8MC&pg=PT59&dq=%22accent+à+couper+au+couteau%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjLq4eXu_fmAhUy8aYKHXqUDwQQ6AEIWTAG#v=onepage&q=%22accent%20à%20couper%20au%20couteau%22&f=false
|page=118
|passage=La manière de parler des Chiliens nous réserve bien des surprises : outre un accent '''à couper au couteau''', ils mangent les mots et ne prononcent aucun ''S'', et ils émaillent leurs phrases de mots inconnus pour nous : ''huahua'' – le bébé –, ''pololo'' –, le petit ami –...|t=The way Chileans speak still has quite a few suprises in store for us: apart from an accent '''you could cut with a knife''', they mumble and do not pronounce their ''s''{{'}}s, and they pepper their speech with words unknown to us: ''huahua'' (baby), ''pololo'' (boyfriend)... }}

====See also====
* {{l|fr|purée de pois}}
types.html:
à couper au couteau (invariable)

  1. (informal, figuratively, of a fog) very dense, very thick, thick as a pea soup
    un brouillard à couper au couteau ― a pea-souper
    • 2010, Michel Castaigna, La Dictée miraculeuse‎[1], page 37:
      Deux heures du matin, se disait-il, moins dix degrés, un brouillard à couper au couteau, un quartier sans intérêt, un mot de passe débile, quelques sous-officiers et sentinelles sans la moindre motivation et cinq cents troufions qui roupillent en attendant le jus tiède du matin [...]
      Two o'clock in the morning, he thought, minus ten degrees, a pea-souper of a fog, nothing interesting in the area, a stupid password, a few NCOs and sentries who had not a shred of motivation, and five-hundred squaddies dozing off as they waited for their warm juice in the morning […]
  2. (informal, figuratively, of an accent) very heavy, very thick, very strong; that you could cut with a knife
    • 2005, Julie Poirier, Au hasard des pistes : Les deux Amériques à vélo‎[2], →ISBN, page 118:
      La manière de parler des Chiliens nous réserve bien des surprises : outre un accent à couper au couteau, ils mangent les mots et ne prononcent aucun S, et ils émaillent leurs phrases de mots inconnus pour nous : huahua – le bébé –, pololo –, le petit ami –...
      The way Chileans speak still has quite a few suprises in store for us: apart from an accent you could cut with a knife, they mumble and do not pronounce their s's, and they pepper their speech with words unknown to us: huahua (baby), pololo (boyfriend)...

See also

[edit]
  • purée de pois
trans: very dense, very thick, thick as a pea soup
very heavy, very thick, very strong
that you could cut with a knife

title: à couper au couteau
pronunHtml:
• IPA(key): /a ku.pe o ku.to/
